Title: "Excellent Establishment for Part-Time College Students"
Pros: Not every restaurant is the same, so I am personally speaking from the Katy, Texas location, yet I'm sure this is common to many of the BJ's locations. The management is communicative and willing to work with your schedule. You're able to pick up shifts when you want, allowing flexibility in your weekly schedule as well. The amount of money that you make depends on your people skills, your ability to act under stress, and any other characteristics typical of a good server, which is my current position. Something that really struck me is how caring corporate is to it's employees. When hurricane Harvey hit, I was pelasantly surprised to find a nice compensation check in the mail from BJ's that was calculated by looking at how much I had worked the previous two weeks, and finding out roughly how much money I lost out on due to the days that our establishment was closed. Even though I lost next-to-nothing compared to many other unfortunate Houstonian's, this compensation was much needed and left a positive lasting impression on me from the company.
Cons: Everywhere you go you'll find some sort of issues with management, and BJ's is no different. I will say that in my time here, the cons are minimal and the biggest con for me is a personal problem, which is the commute to work. Anything else falls on minor communication issues, yet I listed their communication is still good otherwise. The only other thing that I can think of is the high-turnover rate of employees, meaning you may work with some people who aren't good at what they do, slowing you down or messing up your orders, and people who are shady, rude, or unprofessional. I feel as though this is common in many places. Lastly, shifts can be short if that's what you're looking for, but unless you're able to fill your section and stay busy for the entirety of that time, the real money is made staying on longer which isn't always an option.
Advice to Management: Better screening process for applicants

Cons:
*There is not Employee Loyalty

*Every Manager tell you something different- nothing is the same
*Management team is very immature
*Management doesn't listen to you if you need to change your availability and will schedule you to work during time even though you cannot

*You have no idea when the schedule for the following week will be posted

*Post the Schedule every week on the same day at the same time
*Be more Professional
*Have Less Favoritism and reward based on how the job is being executed (performance)
*Be Far and listen to your employees
*When an Employee messages you, message them back so that they know you have read their message.
*Give everyone an opportunity to do each part of the position (such as: Greeting, Seating and Coordinating) Instead of having the same people doing it every shift.
*Due to the fact that Hostess are pay hourly Lunch/Dinner shifts should have the same amount of hours so everyone get the same opportunity whether they work Lunch or Dinner.

-Management is super nice and fun for the most part

-A TON of food items to know about. Massive selection (burgers, pizza, sandwiches, seafood, pasta, etc.) Over 150+ items, 60+ beers, and 20 wines. It's very hard at first after being hired to be put out on the floor and succeed with food knowledge. Takes a couple months to really get it down.

-Suuuuuuper fast employee turnover rate
Advice to Management: Try to pay better attention to the veteran employees who have been there for 1 year+. I have been working at BJ's for over 2 years and am frequently scheduled on holidays even though I ask them off. Also, try to hire more quality employees who you know will be a good fit for the company. Too many bad employees who end up quitting within a couple months of getting the job.

Title: "Typical Corporate Serving Experience"
Pros: I was a server at BJ's for 6 years at 3 different locations (Brea, CA, Vegas, San Bruno, CA), BJ's is a great restaurant to work for. I started as a server but it is definitely easy to move up from host, takeout, or food runner especially if you're working at a busy location. Management is typical of corporate restaurants - you get easy going ones and ones that are nitpicky. Tips are good, depending on location some are great. I would say you make an average of $100 during night shifts, a little less during the day. Good servers get to be in the better sections that usually have booths for families. They also use Hotschedules which makes it easier to get shifts picked up and to pick up shifts. It's a big staff so usually getting shifts covered and/or getting time off isn't an issue. I should say I had a great experience at Brea and Las Vegas.
Cons: It's hard to work at some locations that don't have enough items (silverware, parmesan cheese & peppers, pizza stands, etc). I've only experienced this in the San Bruno location. Makes doing you're job very difficult. Sometimes managers will copy and paste schedule so you have the same schedule for 6 weeks straight (which could be good or bad depending on what your schedule is). Besides that - just the typical server stuff, difficult clientele sometimes, zero table turnover on game days if you're working in the cocktail. Oh and there is usually a decent amount of sidework both during and after your shift so it's not a really a get in get out type of shift. Lots of pre-bussing as well because a lot of the times the bussers don't do that for you. San Bruno was my only true negative experience, great people to work with but clientele wasn't the greatest and most of management didn't help make your job easier. Kitchen staff at this location was particularly bad - felt bad for the customers as the food almost always came out wrong, cold, or just looked bad. Had to deal with this because the customer can only yell at the server, not the cooks. For more detail check our their Yelp page.

Title: "Bj's Restaurant"

I was lucky if I got 2 serving shifts a week and even then I would only get 4-5 tables.
Cons: Besides over-hiring the management was completely incompetent. One manager literally forced me to cover someone else's shift extremely last minute, she wouldn't take "no" for an answer. Another one blamed me for missing points in a health inspection because he thought I dumped a water glass's ice into a back bev's sink (I didn't, it was one of the SA's who did it). Overall this job was extremely stressful and didn't pay well. They took it way too seriously and acted like it was a 5 star restaurant when really all it is is just a chain, pizza and beer joint (with terrible beer).

Huge menu which can be frustrating to try to learn
Advice to Management: Nothing really

Title: "BJ's Line Cook"

Not cool.

Title: "Cupertino Bartender"

Title: "Server"

Advice to Management: Back of the house issues like cleanliness need to be corrected. Don't run out of pizza dough and pizookies when BOGO is going on.

Title: "Host"

Cons: Could ask more questions.

Cons: Because each store is different, the personality of each can vary wildly. They also tend to stick to rigid patterns of business, and could do more to take on new ideas. I also wish our uniforms would stop changing.

Title: "Togo orders and curbside carry out"

Huntsville's building layout cuts off the takeout area from the rest of the restaurant as well. Some days you become an over the phone customer support line.

Title: "Server"

Title: "Haha what a joke!"

Cons: Many may think the servers here make good money because they are busy, but you also have to know how small the kitchen is compared to the seating capacity. Not to mention many of the "cooks" here have never touched a knife or cooked before.
Advice to Management: This is specifically to my first General Manager at BJ's in Dublin, CA (on Fallon): Thanks for telling us that you're set for life because your Dad is super rich! But no need to tell the whole restaurant crew when you got us up at 7 in the AM for a mandatory meeting which consisted of you bragging about your easy life. We were the ones that helped open the restaurant FYI

Title: "Overview"
Pros: flexible hours, tips every time you work, free or 50% off food, fun coworkers
Cons: hard to move up positions, sometimes poor tips

Title: "Add service charge to large parties!"
Pros: Hot schedules, Mostly nice Co workers and managers. They do pre-shift often and restaurant sales continue to go up. Nice location.
Cons: Number one thing that is horrible about BJ's as a company is that they will not add a gratuity/service charge to parties of 8 or more. They do not wish to add it to our paychecks and through the payroll. They care more about the bottom line than their severs. So many managers... and even though most of them are nice some just seem a little lost and not many stay on the floor. There is one that often disappears. They also don't put much thought in scheduling or rotating sections. They are careless when it comes to labor cost. Too many servers are made to stay on the clock and only get one tables or two per hr on slower days and nights. There are so many managers and not one of them thinks about that. With all money wasted on labor cost we could put that towards adding service charges to large parties and making it part of servers paychecks. Many restaurants do that today. I really do like our Gm and a couple of the managers are really good and do seem to care but there are more that shouldn't be in that position. The restaurant isn't very clean and some of the clientele penny pinch on a lot and are pushy to get things free to the point they will complain. Host are not being trained well, they are taught not to be fair and many of them will take these bad habits with them as they advance in life.. hosts will not stay in ration and will often give good tables to only a few severs and continuously give bad tables to new servers. There is usually someone up there directing them on what to do. Hosts never talk about loyalty card.
Advice to Management: Rotate sections, be fair to the staff. Don't disappear for a long time. Cut the floor when it's slow.

Title: "Employee"

Title: "BJs"
Pros: Good pay for a college student

Title: "Disorganized Corporation"
Pros: The team that I work with is amazing. We have a lot of really hard workers who know what they are doing and are passionate about creating the best experience for whomever they come in contact with that day. The food and drinks that we have to offer are also delicious so that is an added bonus as well.
Cons: The restaurant's management is very disorganized. The lack of communication is what kills me the most because each manager is trying to run the restaurant their own way and it contradicts the way that other managers try to run the restaurant when they are managing. Not only is the communication a huge downside to working here, but they view themselves as an untouchable corporation where ideas are immediately turned down because they pay people to do that behind a desk and not on the front lines. It is a very strict workplace and the amount of work that we do is not acknowledged or appreciated, especially from our stronger and more senior staff members. All-in-all, we are not paid fairly for the amount of work that we do.
Advice to Management: If I had to give any advice to my management team, it would be to sync up with the other managers better so that the collective management team is conveying the same message to the rest of the staff and do better at acknowledging those who are bending over backwards for the company on a daily basis. It also wouldn't hurt to back us up when we have ideas or explain to us why the idea isn't a valid one so that we can work together to come up with a better idea as a whole and drive a better customer experience.

Title: "Kitchen Manager"

Advice to Management: Since you don't ever work with the hourly team members, you should stay out of how much of a raise they can get. $.25/hour maximum is not good business practice.

Title: "BJ's Restauant"

Title: "Horrible culture"

Title: "Best Restaurant Climate"
Pros: A company that values their team members and delivers high quality food at a quick pace. Company is growing by leaps and bounds, especially through the Midwest and eastwards. Standards are definitely high but diligent work is rewarded.
Cons: The typical work week, of truly any successful restaurant. Management is scheduled at 50 hour work but, but often exceed that if you are a caring, valuable part of the team. It is a publically traded corporation, so sometimes goals are for the benefit of the quarter instead of the longevity of the restaurant group.
Advice to Management: Time = Quality of life. Figure out how to give enough support to your restaurants to keep the work week below 50 hours a week. Focus on the long range for the future health of the company versus the price of a share in the stock market.

Title: "Experience as a Server & Bartender"
Pros: The restaurant has a strong and popular beer selection for most guests who drink it; because of this, it creates both interest in return and reliable sales.
Cons:
The restaurants are too large and, at times, too busy to accommodate to "gold standard".

Quality of product can greatly fluctuate and the system in place for getting prepared food from the kitchen to the table is weak.

Bartenders and other "tipped out" employees are never guaranteed their money from other team members. The suggested amount to tip out is 0.5%, which while low already, can never be enforced by management.

Bartenders are limited in their abilities replenish stock for both alcoholic and non-alcoholics, therefore heavily dependent upon management support. This then leads to issues with speed of service.

Bartenders are evaluated by secret shoppers, and held accountable for every step in a lengthy service process.
Advice to Management: Listen to the people of your restaurant and less of corporate powers. If the restaurants glassware is limited to serving less than 10% of total restaurant guests, order glassware regardless of what "numbers" your corporate budgets suggest.

Cons: Very restaurant politic-y. Some of the managers only paid attention to the girl servers who flirted with them, and if you didn't follow suit your schedule could suffer greatly.
Advice to Management: Don't let higher management who got in trouble for sexual harassment with an underage hostess come back and work at middle management when they have constant contact with even more girls.

Title: "Robots serving cisco products."

many locations to transfer to
Cons:
Secret shoppers
unrealistic expectations.
Mediocre bill averages.
low quality product, beer and food
server scripts that turn you in to a robot server... "have you made your selections?"
